articles.title: Broward County unveils 50-year Resilience Plan to combat climate challenges
articles.author: Sheri-Kae Mcleod
articles.summary: Broward County has unveiled a 50-year Resilience Plan aimed at preparing the region for the long-term impacts of climate change. It outlines a comprehensive strategy to reduce flood risks, strengthen infrastructure, and improve public health and economic stability. The plan was developed in collaboration with local governments, water control districts, private sector partners, and community members.

articles.title: Impact of climate change on insurance claims and risk assessment
articles.author: Rakesh Jain
articles.summary: Major incidents like Cyclone Amphan, floods in Assam and Kerala, and extended heatwaves across North India have already caused significant losses in the crop and motor insurance segments, especially in the motor and crop insurance segments. The losses are mainly due to the motor insurance segment.

articles.title: Northern Wildfires: Surprisingly Slowing Climate Change?
articles.author: Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: Boreal fires are having a surprising and surprising impact on our planet's climate. The smoke from these intense fires acts like a giant shield, reflecting sunlight back into space. The increased reflection of sunlight from aerosols, and the resulting cooler summers, leads to thicker Arctic ice lasting into the following winter. This cooling effect has also been shown to alter tropical rainfall patterns. Future research will be crucial to investigate the long-term effects of these fire events and how the changing landscape impacts the climate.

articles.title: Forest fire in Musquodoboit Harbour prompts evacuation of community in Halifax area
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Heat Warning from SUN 5:43 AM EDT until WED 6:00 AM EDT. Firefighters with the Department of Natural Resources fight the Seven Mile Lake forest fire in Maitland Bridge, N.S. on Thursday, August 11, 2016. DBC flag wire is true flag sponsored.

articles.title: Some residents allowed to return after forest fire in Halifax area prompts evacuation
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: Heat Warning from SUN 5:11 PM EDT until WED 8:00 PM EDT. Firefighters with the Department of Natural Resources fight the Seven Mile Lake forest fire in Maitland Bridge, N.S. on Thursday, August 11, 2016. DBC flag wire is true flag sponsored.

articles.title: Freak wind gusts made worse by climate change threaten airline passenger safety
articles.author: Lance M Leslie
articles.summary: Unexpected severe turbulence injured crew and passengers on a Qantas Boeing 737 during descent at Brisbane on May 4 2024. Global warming is increasing the frequency and intensity of wind gusts from thunderstorm 'downbursts' with serious consequences for air travel. Increased heat and moisture over eastern Australia are the key ingredients. Small planes with 4-50 seats are more vulnerable to microbursts.

articles.title: Global warming is changing cloud patterns. That means more global warming
articles.author: Christian Jakob
articles.summary: As Earth gets warmer, clouds are changing, adding to the greenhouse heat boost and changing clouds even more. The areas covered by highly reflective clouds are shrinking, while the areas containing broken, less reflective ones are growing. The net effect is that additional energy from sunlight is reaching Earth's surface, leading to extra heating.

articles.title: NGT seeks replies over palm tree felling in state
articles.author: Madan Kumar
articles.summary: The National Green Tribunal has issued notices to the Bihar State Pollution Control Board (BSPCB), the state's disaster management department, the Central Pollution control Board (CPCB) and others in connection with the widespread felling of palm trees in Bihar. The NGT's principal bench in New Delhi took suo motu cognisance of a news report titled "Are missing palm trees causing more lightning deaths in Bihar?" published in TOI on May 29, 2025. According to the news item, palm trees lost their economic value after the ban on toddy tapping due to Bihar's prohibition policy. The area under palm tree cultivation in Bihar has decreased by 40%.

articles.title: How bad can climate damage get? Worse than you imagine
articles.author: David Spratt
articles.summary: Global average warming of 1.5 degrees has now been reached, 15 years earlier than forecast. The running average for the last 24 months has been close to 1.6 degrees. A new World Meteorological Organization report says Earth will cross this point in two years.

articles.title: How bad can climate damage get? Worse than you imagine
articles.author: David Spratt
articles.summary: The past is no longer reliable guide to the future. Australia's recent extreme weather and natural disasters are driven by a hotter climate. The government's assumption that warming would be in the range of 1.5 to 2 degrees by 2050 is way out of date. The current warming trend has already reached the point where it will exceed the previous forecast in two years.

articles.title: The controversial changes the Greens will push on housing reform
articles.author: Connor Pearce
articles.summary: Barbara Pocock is a South Australian Greens senator. She walks through the stately Adelaide Park Lands that circle the CBD. She sees the human impacts of Australia's housing crisis there.    iReport.com will bring you more information on this topic.

articles.title: How bad can climate damage get? Worse than you imagine
articles.author: David Spratt
articles.summary: Australians' recent experience of more extreme weather and natural disasters is due to a hotter climate. The past is no longer a reliable guide to the future, because the past no longer serves as a reliable indicator of the future.    "How bad can climate damage get?" is the question.

articles.title: How bad can climate damage get? Worse than you imagine
articles.author: David Spratt
articles.summary: The past is no longer reliable guide to the future. Australia's recent extreme weather and natural disasters are driven by a hotter climate. The government's assumption that warming would be in the range of 1.5 to 2 degrees by 2050 is way out of date. The current warming trend has already reached the point where it will exceed the previous forecast in two years.

articles.title: How to get the best bang for your climate buck
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: Deniers still exist, but for the most part, they are in stage three. There are still endless debates that we don't need to have. Good policy means tackling climate change in a way that directly benefits citizens and residents of Australia. Taxpayer money is not a magic pudding, so governments need to consider how to get the best bang for their climate buck.

articles.title: How to get the best bang for your climate buck
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: Global warming is now a present reality, not an abstract future threat. Deniers still exist, but for the most part, they are in stage three. A major party proposed with a straight face that we should start a nationally owned, domestic nuclear energy program mostly from scratch.

articles.title: The Guardian view on extreme weather: build national readiness – or let everyday life keep ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Britain's four-day heatwave is made 100 times more likely by the climate crisis. Britain lacks a country adaptation plan. Urgent, coordinated investment is needed to protect lives and infrastructure, writes Simon Tisdall, the author of the book "The Climate Crisis: A Global Perspective".

articles.title: Swiss alps permafrost hits record warmth, triggers hazards
articles.summary: Permafrost in the Swiss Alps is the warmest since records began. The current average near-ground air temperature is about 2.9C higher than the 1871-1900 pre-industrial average. The hydrological years 2022, 2023, and 2024 are among the five warmest years recorded in Switzerland since measurements began in 1864. More than a third of the Swiss Alpine Club's mountain huts could be unstable due to thawing permafrost.

articles.title: Long way to go to stop lending for deforestation
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: Big agribusiness players are still lending to bush-bulldozing businesses. Australian banks have been slow to trim their exposure to deforestation, as shown by their lending to deforestation-related businesses.    .   in this article. In this article, we have stated that the banks have lent money to deforestation deforestation businesses.

articles.title: The Guardian view on extreme weather: build national readiness – or let everyday life keep breaking down
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: Britain's four-day heatwave is expected to claim about 600 lives, especially among older people in cities such as London and Birmingham. There is no national adaptation budget, no cross-government plan and no clear account of what is being spent on climate change adaptation. The London Climate Resilience Review lays out the blueprint: heat plans, flood protection, NHS retrofits and early-warning systems.

articles.title: ‘Dangerously hot' heat wave arrives in Toronto. Here's what you need to know
articles.author: Jermaine Wilson
articles.summary: Environment Canada suggests temperatures could soar between 30 and 36 C. Here's a look at how the city is responding and how residents are reacting to the weather forecast.    i.e. how they are reacting and how they feel about the situation in their area.

articles.title: Sand dune destroyed at Varca, villagers dread seawater ingress
articles.author: Herald Team
articles.summary: A sand dune in Varca Pedda has been destroyed in violation of Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) norms. The incident has sparked outrage among local residents and environmentalists. They are calling for immediate action against the perpetrators and urgent restoration of the damage caused.

articles.title: Toronto's heat wave arrives today. Here's what experts say you need to know
articles.summary: Environment Canada's Dave Phillips and CP24's Phil Perkins discuss the risks associated with extreme heat and what Torontonians should know about the warning they should be aware of.    "Extreme heat" is a warning about the risk of heat-related deaths.

articles.title: The New Normal: Growing Climate Crisis of Heatwaves
articles.author: Varsha Vivek
articles.summary: In 2024, India had its hottest summer since 2010. Global warming is the main cause of extreme weather events like heatwaves, floods, droughts, and storms. Over a billion people in India face heatwaves every year. 57 per cent of Indian districts are at high risk. Vulnerable groups include elderly, children, pregnant women, people with chronic illnesses, slum dwellers, gig workers, police personnel, agricultural labourers, and construction workers.

articles.title: Harsh Middle East climate demands innovative cooling solutions
articles.author: Khaleejtimes
articles.summary: The Middle East presents some of the most extreme climate conditions globally. High humidity, dust, and saline air in certain coastal areas are challenges. These factors demand highly skilled professionals to cope with the climate conditions.    .   in the Middle East.

articles.title: Planetary waves linked to extreme summer weather have tripled, alarming study finds
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: In the 1950s, Earth experienced one extreme weather-causing planetary wave event each summer. Now, we're seeing about three per summer. The phenomenon is linked to the Pacific Northwest heatwave in 2021, the Russian heatwave and Pakistan flooding in 2010, and the lethal European heat wave in 2003. The Arctic is warming at a rate three to four times faster than the rest of the world.

articles.title: Smear yoghurt on your windows during a heatwave, Essex expert says
articles.author: Laura Fidler Reporter
articles.summary: Tom and Kerry Greenhill, both 37, were expecting a baby and looking after their two-year-old during the last major heatwave in 2022. They decided to cover their windows with Greek yoghurt to keep their home cool during the heatwave.

articles.title: 7 Doctor-Approved Tips for Outdoor Fitness Without Injury
articles.summary: There will be a few afternoon clouds, but mostly sunny. High 92F. Winds will be light and variable. Tomorrow will be partly cloudy with a few showers or thunderstorms.    Georgia's weather is expected to be mainly sunny, with a stray shower or thunderstorm.

articles.title: Dawn Chorus: When Migrating Birds Hit the Flyways, I Hit the Highways
articles.author: Wordsand Birds
articles.summary: Mr. WordsandBirds and his partner went to Bowerman Basin to see migratory shorebirds. They saw Caspian Terns, Red Knots, Western Sandpipers, Sanderlings and Short-billed Dowitchers. They also saw a trail of passerines.

articles.title: What's happening to the climate in the Dominican Republic? A look back at 135 years of heat.
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: Jean Suriel has shared a climate snapshot of the Dominican Republic based on the international tool #ShowYourStripes. The data for the country from 1888 to 2024 show an alarming pattern: until 1980, temperatures remained relatively cool, but they intensified between 2000 and 2005. The critical point came in 2015, when the heat began to intensify steadily, reaching its peak in 2024.

articles.title: Economic policymaking needs to adapt to the climate emergency
articles.author: Heather Stewart
articles.summary: Chocolate prices in the UK increased at a record annual rate of 18% last month due to weather-related failures of the cocoa crop in West Africa. $1trn was spent in the US last year on rebuilding and recovery after climate disasters such as wildfires and floods. In the US, wildfires have a direct impact on jobs and earnings, because the smoke affects the health of people far away from the centre of the blaze.

articles.title: State of disaster now 'new normal'
articles.author: e NCA
articles.summary: Nearly 100 people are confirmed dead in the recent floods in the Eastern Cape. The majority of the victims are women and children. The extent of the damage is estimated to be billions of Rand. The floods have brought fundamental change to the province and the country.

articles.title: Riding the Blue Wave: How Los Angeles is Building a Trillion-Dollar Ocean Economy
articles.author: Paul Williams Contributor
articles.summary: The ocean economy in L.A. County provided 105,074 jobs across 3,896 establishments and contributed over $14 billion to county real GDP in 2021. The report was done by the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation and AltaSea at the Port of Los Angeles in collaboration with BECAP.

articles.title: Climate change vs. immigration: assessing threats, getting priorities straight
articles.summary: It took Ron DeSantis and his wife nine months to put their home back together after Hurricane Ian. He cannot identify any moment when undocumented immigrants have disrupted his life. President Trump is prioritizing aggressive efforts to arrest, detain and deport undocumented immigrants at projected costs of $80-88 billion. Algal blooms cost Florida over $25 billion and 43,000 jobs. Hurricane Ian alone cost citrus growers $247 million in losses.

articles.title: This isn't a coincidence. It's physics
articles.summary: The 2025 Atlantic hurricane season is shaping up to be another active one. According to NOAA, there's a 60% chance of an above-normal season and only 10% of a quieter-than-usual one. At Colorado State University, researchers predict an even more active season: 17 named storms, nine hurricanes and four intense hurricanes. The next decade will determine whether future hurricane seasons grow even more severe due to climate change.

articles.title: The Daily Cartoon and Live Briefing: Sunday, June 22, 2025

Al-Anon Family Groups meets every Sunday at Silver Dollar II Club, Suite 707, 2729 E Moody Blvd., Bunnell.

articles.title: SIDS must hold major banks, rich nations to account on climate finance pledge
articles.summary: There is growing concern that international lenders are retreating from their commitments to help increase funding for developing countries' response to global warming. Jamaica is already experiencing some of the effects of climate change in the form of shifting weather patterns. 70 per cent of Jamaica's population live within five kilometres of the sea. The Government had the good sense to format a Climate Change Policy Framework which was approved in 2015.

articles.title: World needs tough actions: Ramesh on climate change concerns
articles.author: Daily Excelsior
articles.summary: 60 scientists from reputed institutions from across the world have just published their third annual update of indicators of global climate change. Continued emissions of all greenhouse gases at current levels would cause human-induced global warming to reach the critical 1.5 degrees Celsius in about five years.

articles.title: Experts warn of record summer heat as dam levels fall in Marmara
articles.author: Daily Sabah With Aa
articles.summary: Rainfall in the Marmara region decreased by 5% compared to the long-term average, but increased by 17%. May can be considered one of the hottest months in recent decades due to the intensive use of fossil fuels, population growth, unplanned urban expansion and deforestation. Dam occupancy levels in the dams that supply Istanbul have fallen below 70%, which could signal water shortages during the summer.

articles.title: Impact of coastal erosion on Wexford beaches raised in the Dáil – ‘Courtown and Kilmichael are in serious danger'
articles.author: Rachel Cahill
articles.summary: Up to 25 per cent of Ireland's coastline is facing the serious problem of coastal erosion. Lifeguards moved northwards to cater for the crowd concentrations at Courtown beach in Gorey. The number of homes at risk in coastal areas grew from 1,445 to 2,279 between 2017 and 2024. Micheál Martin invited the Deputy to make a submission to the Minister for public expenditure.

articles.title: Letters: B.C. underestimating climate impact
articles.author: Coast Reporter
articles.summary: ChatGPT is concerned about B.C.'s climate change record and its role in fueling global warming. The province has missed its climate targets and is contributing to global warming through fossil fuel exports. ChatGPT asks the government to take more action to reduce GHGs and invest more in renewable energy and energy conservation.

articles.title: Predicting 2030: How Climate Change Could Reshape Sports Betting
articles.author: Nathan Spears
articles.summary: In 2030, betting on sports might depend as much on the weather forecast as it does on team form. Leading platforms like Fortunica Casino are already exploring how to adapt their offerings in response to climate change. The Australian Open has seen repeated delays due to extreme heat and poor air quality, and cricket matches in South Asia have been postponed or cancelled.

articles.title: Australian Town Experiences Colder Temperatures Than Antarctica This Morning
articles.author: Internewscast
articles.summary: Some Australians woke up to the coldest June morning in 25 years. In Goulburn, the minimum temperature dropped to -10 degrees. It was colder than Davis Station in Antarctica, where the minimum was -8.4 degrees. Canberra had its coldest morning in 8 years and the iciest June in 39 years. Unusually cold June temperatures are affecting Australia's southeast this weekend.

articles.title: Experts meet to strategise Caribbean climate change, health
articles.author: Paula Lindo
articles.summary: Caricom region is best positioned to act as a champion for making health systems climate resilient. World Health Organisation director of Public Health, Environment and Social Determinants of Health Dr Maria Neira made the call to participants at the three-day conference titled A Regional Response: Advancing Climate And Health Together, held from June 17-19 in Bridgetown, Barbados.

articles.title: MEXICO LATIN AMERICA POPULATION
articles.author: ac vj pa LB
articles.summary: ECLAC warns of dramatic demographic aging in Latin America within 25 years. The region will experience a drastic aging process in the next 25 years, which will put unprecedented pressure on economies and care systems. ECLAC is the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean.

articles.title: The 2025 UN Ocean Conference and Jamaica
articles.summary: The 2025 UN Ocean Conference took place in Nice, France. The declaration 'Our Ocean, Our Future: United for Urgent Action' highlights the existential threats facing marine ecosystems and the need for collective, transformative action. Jamaica's identity and livelihoods are rooted in its coastal and marine resources. The ocean contributes to tourism, fisheries, and biodiversity.

articles.title: Please understand, a liveable future for humanity on this planet is really a very minor concern
articles.summary: Banking on Climate Chaos 2025 is a report on the financing of fossil fuel companies by the world's largest banks. The 65 largest banks committed $869 billion to companies involved in the extraction of oil, coal and gas last year. Two-thirds of them increased their financing by $162 billion from 2023 to 2024. The Paris Agreement aimed at limiting global warming to below 1.5 degrees above industrial levels was signed in 2015.

articles.title: 22 chirps = 17°C?: How crickets became nature's living thermometers
articles.author: Lifestyle Desk
articles.summary: Amos Dolbear first described the cricket chirp as an indicator of the weather in 1897. Dolbear's law states that temperature in degrees Fahrenheit is roughly equal to the number of chirps in 15 seconds plus 40. The chirping rate changes with the temperature because crickets are cold-blooded and their body temperature is the same as their external environment.

articles.title: This renowned climate scientist says this is the most difficult time for climate science he's ever seen
articles.author: Annabelle Choi
articles.summary: Benjamin Santer was the lead author on a chapter of the second Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) in 1995. The chapter confirmed an international scientific consensus that humans were having a discernible impact on the climate. Lobbyist groups accused Santer of removing discussion of scientific uncertainty in the report. Frederick Seitz, former president of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences, wrote an opinion piece in The Wall Street Journal.

articles.title: Australia urges de-escalation as US strikes Iran
articles.author: Kat Wong
articles.summary: The situation in the Middle East continues to devolve following Donald Trump's decision to bomb Iran. Australia has called for a de-escalation in the situation in Middle East. The situation in Mideast continues to deteriorate following Trump's bombing of Iran.

articles.title: WATCH: Brevard Emergency Officials Share Tips on the Proper Use of Sandbags to Protect Your Home
articles.author: Filling sandbags
articles.summary: As hurricane season intensifies, many residents in Brevard County are turning to local Emergency Management officials for guidance on how to protect their homes. One of the most frequently asked questions concerns the use of sandbags, a common yet often misunderstood method of flood prevention. When misused, sandbags offer little to no protection. Homeowners are urged to evaluate their property risks before investing time and energy into sandbagging.

articles.title: The UK seaside town that could soon be under 43 inches of water
articles.author: Jennifer Pinto
articles.summary: Kerrison said sea levels could rise up to 43 inches in Eastbourne by the end of this century. The town's low-lying neighbourhoods including Roselands, Bridgemere, Seaside, Langney, and Sovereign Harbour are especially vulnerable. Eastbourne has the third highest number of properties at risk of being lost due to rising sea levels across England by 2050.

articles.title: Labor must seal the cracks in Australia's carbon credits market
articles.author: Charlotte Hanson
articles.summary: After Labor's election victory, Australia and Pacific countries will co-host next year's global climate summit. There are growing concerns in the business community about ESG risks relating to the offsets market. Labor should bring forward the review of its signature emissions pricing policy to this year.

articles.title: The Human Epoch Doesn't Officially Exist. But We Know When It Began.
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: The Anthropocene epoch is the name given to the period when humans have had a global effect on the planet's climate and ecosystems. New research supports the idea of an early date when European arrival in the Americas first had a notable impact on the atmosphere. Ice core records show a minimum atmospheric methane concentration exactly 100 years after Christopher Columbus first set foot in Americas.

articles.title: Bitter Harvest
articles.summary: Rahim Yar Khan, one of Pakistan's most prominent mango-producers districts, is witnessing a decline in yield due to climate change-induced erratic weather patterns and chronic water shortages. Farmers are forced to choose between watching their orchards die or switching to less water-intensive, lower-value crops. Lawlessness has long plagued Sindh, but the rise in dacoit activity in Upper Sindh is alarming.

articles.title: NSW Weather: Springlike Burst After Antarctic Cold!
articles.author: James Carter
articles.summary: The recent cold snap in New South Wales was a reminder of winter's severity. Forecasters predict a surge of warmth, bringing with it temperatures exceeding average June levels by 5 degrees Celsius. The current shift towards warmer conditions is driven by the movement of a warm air mass across the continent. The interplay of high-pressure systems, like the one that brought the icy conditions, is a key factor. The overall trend points to a warming climate.

articles.title: Australia concerned over escalation as US strikes Iran
articles.author: Kat Wong
articles.summary: The US joined Israel's offensive and attacked Iranian nuclear sites. articles.title: Heated up
articles.author: Hassan Ali Khan
articles.summary: Pakistan is going through a severe heatwave. The region is already dealing with disrupted irrigation plans and water shortages. The combination of heat-stress, water scarcity and failing crops is putting Pakistan in danger of experiencing a severe climate emergency. The government and relevant authorities should implement heat-action plans in urban areas and temporary shifts in irrigation timings.

articles.title: 'Killer bees' keep spreading (and killing) across the US
articles.author: Usatoday
articles.summary: Warmer autumns and winters could put western honey bees at risk of collapse. Fox - Seattle Africanized honey is a good example of a honey bee that didn't give up despite the cold winters and warm autumns. It's a product of the Africanization of honey.

articles.title: How archaeology can offer a blueprint for adapting to climate change
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Scientists from the Université de Montréal propose a workflow for modelers that they can use to integrate human systems into Earth-systems models. They think the key to answering questions about climate change and evolution is to pay more attention to the archaeological record.

articles.title: Solar flares may trigger short-term weather shifts on planets: study
articles.author: China.dot.org
articles.summary: Solar flares from stars can cause rapid weather changes on planets, even here on Earth, according to scientists at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem. Their findings were published in The Astronomical Journal. They claim that flares from a star can shape the weather systems of planets.

articles.title: OPINION: In the U.S., golden eagles are expendable; spotted owls are not
articles.author: Commentary
articles.summary: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service doesn't have an online clearinghouse that would tell the public how many golden eagles have been killed by windmills in the past year. Environmentalists are concerned with the welfare of threatened and endangered species. The 2022 estimate of the golden eagle population in the western United States is about 31,800 eagles of all ages. 80% of the population lives west of the Rocky Mountains.
